ANU.name: Stephanie Pulsford
ANU.biography: Stephanie completed her PhD on reptile and frog ecology and conservation in agricultural woodland landscapes. Her doctoral research explored how different management actions in grazing landscapes affect populations. She also tutored undergraduate classes at the ANU and was an associate of the Centre of Excellence in Environmental Decisions.

publication.title: Reptiles and frogs use most land cover types as habitat in a fine-grained agricultural landscape
Reptiles and frogs conform to multiple conceptual landscape models in an agricultural landscape
publication.source: Diversity and Distributions, vol. 23, no. 12, pp. 1408-1422

publication.title: Remnant vegetation, plantings and fences are beneficial for reptiles in agricultural landscapes
Pasture height and crop direction influence reptile movement in an agricultural matrix
publication.source: Agriculture Ecosystems and Environment, vol. 235, pp. 164-171

publication.title: succession of theories: purging redundancy from disturbance theory. Biological Reviews

Microsoft-Academic.title: reptile and frog responses to different farm management practices in grazing landscapes
